Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 218, § 19, as this matter is a civil case that includes damages below the threshold amount for jurisdiction in the Superior Court.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Brockton District Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, §§ 8 and 9, as the property in question is located in Brockton and the Defendant resides in Massachusetts.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14 provides that any tenant whose quiet enjoyment is substantially interfered with may recover actual damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater.

Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988).proposition: A substantial breach of quiet enjoyment occurs when conditions unreasonably interfere with use of the rental.
Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard for breach of quiet enjoyment in terms of “substantial injury” and “serious interferences,” not in terms of an “unreasonable interference with use of the rental.” While the court upholds liability based on significant noise from an alarm as a possible substantial interference, it does not articulate or adopt an “unreasonableness” test as the proposition states. Thus, the wording of the claimed proposition is not accurately supported by this case, even though it is broadly consistent with the idea of substantial interference.
Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988).relevant_excerpt: “A landlord will be liable for interference with quiet enjoyment if he causes or authorizes acts which result in ‘substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises.’ … The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects the ‘tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy.’ … We do not have a transcript of the evidence, and the only question before us on this issue is whether, as a matter of law, the noise of an alarm ringing for more than one day could not support a finding of a breach of the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Landlord liability for breach of quiet enjoyment under ch. 186, § 14.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion involves a tenant’s counterclaims including breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the trial judge dismissed that counterclaim to avoid cumulative damages and the Supreme Judicial Court does not analyze or affirm any award under § 14. The decision instead addresses damages under c. 93A and warranty of habitability, and provides no substantive discussion or holding on landlord liability for breach of quiet enjoyment under c. 186, § 14. Thus it does not serve as authority for that specific proposition.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: After his view, the judge made express findings... Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims. To avoid awarding cumulative damages, however, the judge dismissed all but the retaliation and c. 93A counterclaims.

Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355.raw_text: Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355 Mass. 665 (1969)
Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355.proposition: Quiet enjoyment includes basic living conditions, such as heat and hot water.
Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355.case_name: Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Savings Bank
Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355.support_reasoning: The excerpt from Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Savings Bank concerns whether violation of a building code provision can be evidence of negligence in maintaining building conditions, particularly regarding structural issues and sprinklers. It does not address the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or whether that covenant includes basic living conditions such as heat and hot water. Therefore, this case does not support the specific proposition about quiet enjoyment covering basic living conditions.
Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355.relevant_excerpt: I concur in the result of part 1 of the opinion on the ground that (subject to proof of other elements of liability, see Wainwright v. Jackson, 291 Mass. 100, 102-103) violation of § 1008 (a) of the Boston Building Code may be found to be evidence of negligence; i.e. failure to “exercise reasonable care to keep” a portion of the building (not a common area and not part of the premises let to the plaintiff) “in such condition that others will not be injured.”

Armstrong v. Werstine, 33 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Armstrong v. Werstine, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 690 (1992)
Armstrong v. Werstine, 33 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Lack of essential services like heat and hot water constitutes a breach.
Armstrong v. Werstine, 33 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns whether an oral partnership existed and whether the jury was properly instructed on partnership law. It does not address landlord-tenant law, habitability, or the provision of essential services such as heat or hot water. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that lack of essential services constitutes a breach.
Armstrong v. Werstine, 33 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: The provided text contains no discussion of essential services, heat, hot water, or habitability; it focuses solely on partnership formation, profit-sharing, and jury instructions relating to partnership versus employee status.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: Although this is a concurring/dissenting opinion and the author disagrees with the majority’s chosen doctrinal label, he expressly agrees that the old no‑warranty, caveat‑emptor rule for residential leases should be abandoned and replaced with an implied obligation tied to habitability standards. He recognizes that the majority opinion adopts an implied warranty of fitness/habitability and concurs in the core result limiting rent to the reasonable value of the premises in light of code violations, so the case as a whole is authoritative for the implied warranty of habitability in Massachusetts.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair….’ … The opinion of the court accomplishes this. … The point at which I dissent from the opinion of the court is where it attempts to accomplish the first step by resort to an implied warranty of the fitness of the rented dwelling unit….”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Damages for breach of quiet enjoyment include emotional distress.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory quiet enjoyment claim) to allow recovery of emotional distress as part of the tenant’s “actual and consequential damages.” It explicitly states that personal injuries, including emotional distress, are within the scope of statutory damages for interference with quiet enjoyment and then treats Solomon’s emotional distress as compensable under that provision when upholding the attorney’s fees award. Although the separate $10,000 quiet-enjoyment verdict was vacated as duplicative, the opinion clearly recognizes emotional distress as a proper measure of damages for breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises. … The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery. In the present case, not only were Solomon’s injuries foreseeable, but the jury found specifically that Gem knew or should have known that if it permitted floods to occur, Solomon would suffer emotional harm. Therefore, Solomon’s claim for emotional distress was within the scope of § 14…”

Davis v. Alden, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 833 (2.raw_text: Davis v. Alden, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 833 (2002)
Davis v. Alden, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 833 (2.proposition: Reaffirmation of tenant rights under quiet enjoyment terms.
Davis v. Alden, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 833 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns Fourth Amendment and Massachusetts search-and-seizure law, specifically whether there was probable cause to search a defendant’s residence for drugs. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, leases, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it address tenant rights in any way. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for a proposition about reaffirmation of tenant rights under quiet enjoyment terms.
Davis v. Alden, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 833 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Although the question is close, we conclude that probable cause to believe there were drugs at the defendant’s house was lacking. We are mindful that the magistrate’s determination of probable cause is due great deference. … In sum, the evidence before the magistrate did not constitute a ‘substantial basis’ … to believe there were drugs in the defendant’s home. The motion to suppress should have been allowed.”

Yee v. Mass. State Lottery Comm\u2019n,.raw_text: Yee v. Mass. State Lottery Comm’n, 392 Mass. 225 (1984)
Yee v. Mass. State Lottery Comm\u2019n,.proposition: Standard for assessing actual damages in breach claims.
Yee v. Mass. State Lottery Comm\u2019n,.case_name: Coco v. School Committee of Boylston
Yee v. Mass. State Lottery Comm\u2019n,.support_reasoning: The opinion is about statutory protections for tenured teachers’ salaries and the meaning of “reduction in salary” under G.L. c. 71, § 43, not about the general contract-law standard for calculating actual damages in breach of contract claims. While the court affirms an award of compensation, it does not articulate any damages formula, measure, or standard; it focuses on whether the salary reduction was lawful and whether reinstatement without loss of compensation is required by statute. Therefore it does not support a proposition about the standard for assessing actual damages in breach claims.
Yee v. Mass. State Lottery Comm\u2019n,.relevant_excerpt: “We therefore hold that the reduction in the plaintiff’s salary was in violation of G. L. c. 71, § 43, and affirm the award of compensation granted by the judge of the Superior Court.”

McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.raw_text: McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429 Mass. 300 (1999)
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.proposition: Landlords must act in a timely manner to resolve habitability issues.
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a landlord’s duty to remove snow and ice and whether breach of that duty can be framed as negligence, quiet enjoyment, or breach of habitability, but it does not discuss any requirement that landlords act in a ‘timely’ manner to resolve habitability issues. The court actually narrows habitability by holding that natural accumulations of snow and ice are not the sort of defects that implicate the implied warranty of habitability at all. Thus, it neither articulates nor applies any timeliness standard for correcting habitability problems.
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.relevant_excerpt: “The implied warranty of habitability ‘is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises’ (emphasis in original)… Not every breach of the State sanitary code supports a claim under the implied warranty of habitability. Rather, the implied warranty of habitability applies to significant defects in the property itself… The natural accumulation of snow and ice is not such a defect… Thus, the directed verdict on the implied warranty of habitability claim was proper.”
